content.text: C++ Exceptions
C++ Exceptions
When executing C++ code, different errors can occur: coding errors made by the programmer, errors due to wrong input, or other unforeseeable things.
content.html: When executing C++ code, different errors can occur: coding errors made by the programmer, errors due to wrong input, or other unforeseeable things.

content.text: When an error occurs, C++ will normally stop and generate an error message. The technical term for this is: C++ will throw an exception (throw an error).
content.html: When an error occurs, C++ will normally stop and generate an error message. The technical term for this is: C++ will throw an exception (throw an error).

content.text: C++ try and catch
Exception handling in C++ consist of three keywords: try , throw and catch :
content.html: Exception handling in C++ consist of three keywords: try, throw and catch:

content.text: The try statement allows you to define a block of code to be tested for errors while it is being executed.
content.html: The try statement allows you to define a block of code to be tested for errors while it is being executed.

content.text: The throw keyword throws an exception when a problem is detected, which lets us create a custom error.
content.html: The throw keyword throws an exception when a problem is detected, which lets us create a custom error.

content.text: The catch statement allows you to define a block of code to be executed, if an error occurs in the try block.
content.html: The catch statement allows you to define a block of code to be executed, if an error occurs in the try block.

content.text: The try and catch keywords come in pairs:

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Throw an exception when a problem arise
// Block of code to handle errors

syntax_highlighting.text: // Throw an exception when a problem arise
// Block of code to handle errors

content.code_html:
try {
  // Block of code to try
  throw exception; // Throw an exception when a problem arise
}
catch () {
  // Block of code to handle errors
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Throw an exception when a problem arise
// Block of code to handle errors

content.text: Consider the following example:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
"Access denied - You must be at least 18 years 
    old.\n"

syntax_highlighting.text:
"Access denied - You must be at least 18 years 
    old.\n"

content.code_html:
try {
  int age = 15;
  if (age >= 18) {
    cout << "Access granted - you are old enough.";
  } else {
    throw (age);
  }
}
catch (int myNum) {
  cout << "Access denied - You must be at least 18 years old.\n";
  cout << "Age is: " << myNum;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
"Access denied - You must be at least 18 years 
    old.\n"

content.text: Example explained
We use the try block to test some code: If the age variable is less than 18 , we will throw an exception, and handle it in our catch block.
content.html: We use the try block to test some code: If the age variable is less than 18, we will throw an exception, and handle it in our catch block.

content.text: In the catch block, we catch the error and do something about it. The catch statement takes a parameter : in our example we use an int variable ( myNum ) (because we are throwing an exception of int type in the try block ( age )), to output the value of age .
content.html: In the catch block, we catch the error and do something about it. The catch statement takes a parameter: in our example we use an int variable (myNum) (because we are throwing an exception of int type in the try block (age)), to output the value of age.

content.text: If no error occurs (e.g. if age is 20 instead of 15 , meaning it will be be greater than 18), the catch block is skipped:
content.html: If no error occurs (e.g. if age is 20 instead of 15, meaning it will be be greater than 18), the catch block is skipped:

content.code_html: int age = 20;

content.text: You can also use the throw keyword to output a reference number, like a custom error number/code for organizing purposes ( 505 in our example):
content.html: You can also use the throw keyword to output a reference number, like a custom error number/code for organizing purposes (505 in our example):

syntaxHighlighting.text: "Access denied - You must be at least 18 years old.\n"

syntax_highlighting.text: "Access denied - You must be at least 18 years old.\n"

content.code_html:
try {
  int age = 15;
  if (age >= 18) {
    cout << "Access granted - you are old enough.";
  } else {
    throw 505;
  }
}
catch (int myNum) {
  cout << "Access denied - You must be at least 18 years old.\n";
  cout << "Error number: " << myNum;
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text: "Access denied - You must be at least 18 years old.\n"

content.text: Handle Any Type of Exceptions (...)
If you do not know the throw type used in the try block, you can use the "three dots" syntax ( ... ) inside the catch block, which will handle any type of exception:
content.html: If you do not know the throw type used in the try block, you can use the "three dots" syntax (...) inside the catch block, which will handle any type of exception:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
"Access denied - You must be at least 18 years 
    old.\n"

syntax_highlighting.text:
"Access denied - You must be at least 18 years 
    old.\n"

content.code_html:
try {
  int age = 15;
  if (age >= 18) {
    cout << "Access granted - you are old enough.";
  } else {
    throw 505;
  }
}
catch (...) {
  cout << "Access denied - You must be at least 18 years old.\n";
}

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
"Access denied - You must be at least 18 years 
    old.\n"

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
What is the purpose of exception handling in C++?
content.html: What is the purpose of exception handling in C++?

metadata.question: What is the purpose of exception handling in C++?

options.text: To handle errors and execute code when an error occurs
To organize code into classes and objects

content.question: What is the purpose of exception handling in C++?

options.text: To handle errors and execute code when an error occurs
To organize code into classes and objects
